nodes.text: A correspondence exists between ergodicity economics (agents maximizing time-average wealth growth) and expected utility theory (agents maximizing expected utility) such that the ergodicity transformation in the former can be identified as the utility function in the latter, implying wealth dynamics determine apparent risk preferences
Ergodicity economics distinguishes time averages from expectation values and focuses on mechanistically relevant time-average growth rates for single-agent wealth trajectories
Ergodicity economics postulates that agents maximize the long-time-average growth rate of wealth (growth optimality) instead of expectation values over hypothetical ensembles

The proposed correspondence: if an ergodicity transformation u(x) exists for given wealth dynamics, then the time-average growth-rate maximand equals the expected rate of change of u(x), making expected-utility maximization equivalent to time optimization

Model wealth as a stochastic process (It么 SDE) and introduce a monotonically increasing transformation u(x); require the increments of u(t) to be stationary and independent so time and ensemble averages of its rate coincide

For equivalence between expected-utility optimization and time-average growth optimization, utility u(t) must follow an additive stochastic process with stationary increments, taken as Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW
Use It么 calculus: given invertible u(x) with sufficient smoothness, apply It么's lemma to du = a_u dt + b_u dW to derive the corresponding wealth SDE dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW (explicit mapping eqn)

Theorem: Every invertible utility function u(x) corresponds to a unique class of wealth dynamics for which maximizing expected changes in u is equivalent to maximizing time-average wealth growth; conversely, given certain wealth dynamics a corresponding u(x) exists if consistency conditions hold
Example: Linear utility u(x)=x corresponds to additive Brownian-motion wealth dynamics (dx = a dt + b dW)
Example: Logarithmic utility u(x)=ln x corresponds to multiplicative (geometric Brownian) wealth dynamics (dx = x[(a_u + 1/2 b_u^2) dt + b_u dW])

Example: Square-root utility u(x)=sqrt(x) maps to a mixed dynamic with both additive and multiplicative components (SDE with drift containing x-dependent and constant parts and noise proportional to sqrt(x)), akin to Cox-Ingersoll-Ross form

Constructed example: wealth dynamic with noise b_x(x)=e^{-x} yields exponential utility u(x)=b_u e^{x}+C, producing dynamics where fluctuations shrink at high wealth and a derived analytical wealth distribution (via transform of normal u(t))

Empirical evidence from experiments with controllable wealth dynamics supports the prediction that dynamics strongly determine preferences, consistent with ergodicity economics over fixed-preference EUT

Implication: Since wealth dynamics are defined exogenously, ergodicity economics provides a theoretical basis to predict an agent's apparent utility function a priori from the dynamics, and predicts that changes in dynamics change apparent preferences
Assumption: Wealth dynamics are exogenous and decision times are such that the increments and mappings (invertibility, differentiability) required for the It么-based correspondence are available

Limitation/constraint: The correspondence requires invertible, sufficiently smooth (twice-differentiable) utility functions and wealth processes that satisfy consistency relations; pathological processes exist for which no u(x) with Brownian increments exists

Interpretation: Non-linear utility functions can be reinterpreted as encoding non-linear wealth dynamics rather than as purely psychological risk attitudes; expected utility theory historically patched non-ergodicity but ergodicity economics offers a mechanistic foundation
